{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-124-03-B |Item_parent=Menopause, premature ovarian failure, andropause, age-related androgen deficiency (See item 330) |Item_parent_short=Menopause, premature ovarian failure, andropause, age-related androgen deficiency (See item 330) |Rank=B |Title=Know the definition and diagnosis of premature ovarian failure. |Description=None |Topic=Positive diagnosis |Contributors=Florence Trémollieres,Anna Gosset |Order=3}} Premature ovarian failure (POI) is defined by - primary or secondary amenorrhoea lasting more than 4 months - '''before the age of 40''' - associated with an ''increase in pituitary gonadotropins''. Diagnostic confirmation is based on an increase in FSH > 25 IU/l combined with estradiol < 20 pg/ml on 2 occasions 4 weeks apart. Its prevalence is around 1 to 2%. Familial forms account for 10-15% of cases, but in 80% of cases no aetiology is found. The main causes of POI are : {| class="wikitable" |'''Causes''' |'''Pathologies''' |'''Mechanisms''' |- |'''Genetics''' |Turner Syndrome Premutation of the FMR1 gene Other genetic causes : ''Gonadal dysgenesis ...''
|Acceleration of apoptosis
|- |'''Auto-immune''''' |Type I (APECED) and type II polyendocrinopathy POI associated with other autoimmune diseases Isolated ovarian failure |Blockage of follicular maturation |- |Toxicology |Chemotherapy Radiotherapy |Acceleration of apoptosis
|}

question.question: What is the primary diagnostic criterion for premature ovarian failure (POI)?
question.option_a: Primary or secondary amenorrhoea lasting more than 6 months
question.option_c: FSH > 30 IU/l combined with estradiol < 15 pg/ml
